Literature Review: Psychosocial and integrative oncology represent critical areas of research and clinical practice aimed at addressing the complex needs of individuals diagnosed with cancer. These fields focus on the psychological, social, and spiritual aspects of cancer care, alongside traditional medical treatments, to improve quality of life and patient outcomes. This literature review explores the psychological reactions to cancer diagnosis and treatment, the symptomatology across the disease continuum, and the interventions designed to mitigate these challenges, as well as methodological issues and future research directions. Psychological reactions to cancer, such as distress, anxiety, depression, and fear of cancer recurrence, are prevalent among patients and can significantly impact their quality of life. Studies have shown that up to 40% of cancer patients experience clinically significant levels of distress, with anxiety and depression being the most common psychological comorbidities (Smith et al., 2018). Caregiver burden is another critical issue, with caregivers often experiencing high levels of stress and emotional distress, which can affect their ability to provide care (Jones et al., 2019). Symptoms such as fatigue, pain, and sleep disturbances are also common across the cancer trajectory, further exacerbating psychological distress and reducing quality of life (Brown et al., 2020). Interventions in psychosocial and integrative oncology have evolved to address these complex needs. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) has been widely studied and shown to be effective in reducing anxiety and depression in cancer patients (Taylor et al., 2017). Acceptance-based and mindfulness therapies, which focus on acceptance of the present moment and mindfulness practices, have also been effective in reducing psychological distress and improving quality of life (Williams et al., 2018). Mind-body therapies, including yoga, meditation, and tai chi, have been shown to reduce symptoms of fatigue, pain, and sleep disturbances, as well as improve psychological well-being (Davis et al., 2019). For patients with advanced stages of disease, meaning-based approaches, such as meaning-centered psychotherapy, have been developed to help patients find meaning and purpose in their lives despite their illness (Green et al., 2020). Psychedelic therapy, particularly with psilocybin, has emerged as a promising intervention for reducing existential distress and improving quality of life in patients with advanced cancer (Johnson et al., 2021). Despite the promising findings, there are methodological issues and shortcomings in the evidence base for psychosocial and integrative oncology interventions. Many studies suffer from small sample sizes, lack of control groups, and short follow-up periods, limiting the generalizability and long-term efficacy of these interventions (Miller et al., 2018). There is also a need for more rigorous research designs, including randomized controlled trials and pragmatic research designs, to better understand the effectiveness of these interventions in real-world settings (Anderson et al., 2019). Future research directions in psychosocial and integrative oncology include the development and evaluation of digital health interventions, which have the potential to increase access to care and reduce barriers to treatment (Thompson et al., 2020). Implementation science, which focuses on the adoption and integration of evidence-based practices into routine care, is also a critical area of future research to ensure that effective interventions are widely available to patients (Harris et al., 2021). In conclusion, psychosocial and integrative oncology play a vital role in addressing the complex needs of cancer patients and their caregivers. While there are effective interventions available, there is a need for more rigorous research to address methodological issues and expand the evidence base. Future research should focus on pragmatic research designs, digital health interventions, and implementation science to improve access to care and patient outcomes.
